reviewText: This is a reasonably paced movie which managed to hold my attention without too much difficulty. If you're a sci-fi/disaster flick fan you'll probably enjoy the movie and feel your time was not wasted. There is a lot of science fantasy mixed in with a teen age prodigy accomplishing amazing technological breakthroughs in a college library setting.If one is prepared to accept the assumptions of the movie and move on the movie is sufficiently entertaining to carry the evening. The special effects aren't too bad and the concept of the problem is timely as we seem to be approaching a solar maximum in the 2012-2013 timeframe. There has been some speculation as to the effects this solar maximum will have on our technology with some comparisons being made to the 1859 Carrington Event.I've read estimates from the scientific community that another event of similar severity could cause huge damage to our technological infrastructure and take 4 to 10 years to recover. There appears to be no real idea how severe this next event could actually be; at least we don't have long to wait to find out.If you have any further interest in this subject you may want to enter, carrington event year 1859, into your search engine.
summary: Sci-fi Disaster Flick of Timely Interest

Title: N/A

reviewText: Another one of those made for TV disaster flicks featuring the usual characters and a rather incredulous premise.  Seems like a bunch of storms are going to merge together all around the globe and predicate a new ice age.  Researcher Joanna Pacula is the only one (naturally) who realizes this and most of the movie is spent with her trying to convince disbelieving faculty members and a stern general.  Meanwhile we get another 15 year old genius (Pacula's son) who we know is going to come up with the solution to save the day, but not before the usual family problems, the most serious being the arrival of his real mother.  Meanwhile lightning strikes a few buildings and provides about as much suspense as a carousel ride.Moderately diverting but nothing special.
Title: N/A
